title: Could Mauricio Pochettino or Zinedine Zidane trigger a huge shake-up of managers?
text:
One top manager moving can trigger a raft of switches across Europe and, with a number of jobs up in the air even as early as October, that could play out this season - starting with Mauricio Pochettino.

Pochettino's future at Tottenham is far from certain, while there are a few big-name managers waiting for their next projects.

Here, Sportsmail looks at those who are likely to be involved in a managerial shake-up in the coming months.

Mauricio Pochettino

Sportsmail revealed that Tottenham's players fear that Pochettino could walk away and, given Daniel Levy would have to part with £32million to sack him, resignation seems the only way of divorce.

Manchester United have been huge admirers of the Argentine and even looked at him before appointing Jose Mourinho in 2016, let alone last year.

But Real Madrid is a prospect that intrigues Pochettino too and his future could end up depending on that of Zinedine Zidane.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino's future is uncertain with his players fearing an exit

Zinedine Zidane

An inauspicious start to the Champions League campaign – a heavy defeat and Tuesday's comeback draw against Club Brugge – has further piled on the pressure during this tricky second spell in charge for Zidane

They might sit top of a congested La Liga but rumblings at Real Madrid are persisting, with criticism levelled at the boss over his treatment of Gareth Bale and James Rodriguez this week. The Spanish media are on his case, which represents an indication of what Real's hierarchy are thinking.

Where Zidane would go next is up for debate. Former club Juventus, perhaps? Or eventually cash-rich Paris Saint-Germain? It remains to be seen whether he stays in management at all.

Zinedine Zidane has Real Madrid top of La Liga - but they have been poor in Europe this season

Jose Mourinho

Mourinho has maintained throughout the year that he is waiting for a top job following his sacking at United last December. The former Chelsea boss has turned down a number of offers already, with the most high profile being the £89.6m contract at Guangzhou Evergrande in China.

The Portuguese's managerial future appears to be in the hands of Pochettino and Zidane to an extent, with Real and Tottenham both linked with moves for him.

There is unfinished business in Madrid, while Mourinho has emerged as the bookies' favourite to take over at Spurs. For now, he seems content reinventing himself in the Sky Sports studio - albeit with one eye on any vacant spots on the touchlines of the top teams...

Jose Mourinho is happy working in punditry for now - until a big managerial job comes up

Massimiliano Allegri

Allegri certainly has his eyes on the United job. The former Juve boss has been learning English in readiness for a move to the Premier League during a year out from coaching.

You wonder whether his desire to work in England may work in the favour of others – namely Tottenham – should United keep Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in the longer term.

Allegri's stock remains high after five Serie A titles and taking Juventus to two Champions League finals.

Massimiliano Allegri is keen on a Premier League move and has been learning English

Eddie Howe

Howe's position is an interesting one. The Bournemouth boss is rarely talked up for the bigger Premier League jobs with any sort of gusto and is almost viewed as a left-field alternative.

Aside from a year at Burnley he has managed the Cherries since 2008, solidifying them as a top-flight club and playing attractive football with it.

Howe is known to be settled down on the south coast but when does the time come for him to kick on and further his career? The London clubs must be looking at him when their next cycle of managerial switches come around. Arsenal are often mooted but Daniel Levy is an admirer, too.
